951855077655961600.text: .@fransrosen found a security vulnerability that caused @letsencrypt to permanently disable TLS-SNI-01 and TLS-SNI-02. Here's what he found: https://labs.detectify.com/2018/01/12/how-i-exploited-acme-tls-sni-01-issuing-lets-encrypt-ssl-certs-for-any-domain-using-shared-hosting/ …. Amazing find!

951355749011144705.text: Highly recommend the mozilla-dev-security-policy thread for some lively debate from both sides. I am also firmly in the "protocol should prevent it by design" camphttps://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/mozilla.dev.security.policy/RHsIInIjJA0 …

951332747733356544.text: We should not forget that the TLS-SNI design does not enforce a method to prevent this. I would definitely say this is a vulnerability in ACME, but indeed only exposed when not carefully implemented. There will always be providers that make this simple mistake again.

951042534989619200.text: To clarify, LE aren't at fault here, they were/are operating in a spec compliant manner and would be perfectly entitled to continue doing so. They have chosen to do the right thing and try to rectify problems that exist elsewhere. Bravo good people, bravo!

1015289018584588288.text: The reason to find the bucket is to make further ACL-checks on the bucket. When the bucket is hidden behind a CDN, you cannot make proper requests to the bucket so no ACL-checks can be made, that's why you need the bucket name.

1015288680498515971.text: Many of the times, a specific path (/files/, /static/ etc) is used as a reverse proxy to S3, this script will to decloak those cases as well.

1015287960277868545.text:
I read the S3-docs and found that signing-errors disclosed the bucket-name. This can be used when CDNs are put in front of a bucket. It doesn't work in all cases, but many of them. You need an access-key to make it work (no secret-key)

A stupid little bash-profile alias to turn any command into a console:
function consolify { while [ true ]; do echo -n "$@ "; read p; $@ $p; done }
Usage:
$ consolify ./something.sh
Everything you enter will now be arguments to ./something.sh until you quit

944488486350008320.text: Wild guess: NameSRS is a reseller network. One reseller are updating their assets. For some reason blocket.se was included in the bulk update. NameSRS' API of updating records did not validate the ownership of every domain, and allowed it to be changed.

944396001594441728.text: It looks like someone is changing their nameserver for all their assets (like 400k domains) but that doesn't explain why one of the largest sites in Sweden were affected. Still trying to figure this out..

944381817704124416.text: Someone is currently hijacking thousands of .se and .nu with NameSRS set as registrar. Zone files of .SE and .NU (https://zonedata.iis.se ) shows thousands of domains changed in the last hours, one of the biggest sites in Sweden (blocket.se) was also affected.
